articles.headline: University of Missouri Protests Spur a Day of Change
articles.snippet: After the football team added its clout to protests over racial issues, Timothy Wolfe announced that he was stepping down as president of the four-campus system, and the chancellor, R. Bowen Loftin, said he would move into another job.
articles.abstract: After the football team added its clout to protests over racial issues, Timothy Wolfe announced that he was stepping down as president of the four-campus system, and the chancellor, R. Bowen Loftin, said he would move into another job.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, Mo. — Months of student and faculty protests over racial tensions and other issues that all but paralyzed the University of Missouri campus culminated Monday in an extraordinary coup for the demonstrators, as the president of the university system resigned and the chancellor of the flagship campus here said he would step down to a less prominent role at the end of the year.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Campbell Rethinks Its Soup Recipe as Consumer Tastes Change
articles.snippet: Hoping to bolster sales, Campbell Soup is updating its classic chicken noodle soup, as well as the way it does business.
articles.abstract: Hoping to bolster sales, Campbell Soup is updating its classic chicken noodle soup, as well as the way it does business.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMDEN, N.J. — Food companies tinker with the signature products in their portfolios at their own risk — and few products are as classic as Campbell’s chicken noodle soup.

articles.headline: VW Looks at Cost Cuts and Offers Money to Diesel Car Owners
articles.snippet: The company will meet with worker representatives about how to cut costs following the emissions scandal. VW is also offering up to $1,000 to owners.
articles.abstract: The company will meet with worker representatives about how to cut costs following the emissions scandal. VW is also offering up to $1,000 to owners.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen said on Monday that it would begin talks with worker representatives about how to cut costs, in the latest sign that the company’s crisis over cheating on emissions tests is taking a heavy toll.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Cuban Peers Dispute Ted Cruz’s Father’s Story of Fighting for Castro
articles.snippet: The family narrative that has provided such inspirational fire and biographical heft to Mr. Cruz’s campaign is, his father’s former comrades and friends say, an embroidered one.
articles.abstract: The family narrative that has provided such inspirational fire and biographical heft to Mr. Cruz’s campaign is, his father’s former comrades and friends say, an embroidered one.
articles.lead_paragraph: MATANZAS, Cuba — Since he was a boy, Senator Ted Cruz has said, all he wanted to do was “fight for liberty” — a yearning that he says was first kindled when he heard his father’s tales of fighting as a rebel leader in Cuba in the 1950s, throwing firebombs, running guns and surviving torture.

articles.headline: Canadian Pacific Said to Weigh Deal for Norfolk Southern
articles.snippet: The preliminary discussions may lead to a new round of consolidation within the railroad industry.
articles.abstract: The preliminary discussions may lead to a new round of consolidation within the railroad industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: If at first Canadian Pacific could not succeed in buying a fellow railroad operator, it looks prepared to try again with another target.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Pimco Suit Sheds Light on Murky Investor Fees
articles.snippet: As Pimco copes with an exodus of cash from its largest fund after the departure of its co-founder William H. Gross, lucrative fees are drawing scrutiny.
articles.abstract: As Pimco copes with an exodus of cash from its largest fund after the departure of its co-founder William H. Gross, lucrative fees are drawing scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the trading desks of investment banks cut to the bone, the ability to pin a fat fee on a fast-growing pile of assets has become the holy grail for financial firms.

articles.headline: Bill Ackman’s Enigmatic Approach to Valeant Pharmaceuticals
articles.snippet: Bill Ackman has led something of a crusade on moral grounds against Herbalife, a nutritional supplements company, but he seems unperturbed by Valeant’s rapacious re-pricing of old drugs.
articles.abstract: Bill Ackman has led something of a crusade on moral grounds against Herbalife, a nutritional supplements company, but he seems unperturbed by Valeant’s rapacious re-pricing of old drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman, the activist investor, has described his billion-dollar bet and continuing crusade against the nutritional supplements company Herbalife as a “moral obligation.” In at least one presentation, he nearly cried onstage and said that if his Herbalife trade was successful, he would give the profits to charity because he would consider them “blood money.”

articles.headline: Classified Report on the C.I.A.’s Secret Prisons Is Caught in Limbo
articles.snippet: Nearly a year after the Senate released a declassified summary of a report on the C.I.A.’s secret prison program, the full document is the subject of battles in the courts and in Congress.
articles.abstract: Nearly a year after the Senate released a declassified summary of a report on the C.I.A.’s secret prison program, the full document is the subject of battles in the courts and in Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Senate security officer stepped out of the December chill last year and delivered envelopes marked “Top Secret” to the Pentagon, the C.I.A., the State Department and the Justice Department. Inside each packet was a disc containing a 6,700-page classified report on the C.I.A.’s secret prison program and a letter from Senator Dianne Feinstein, urging officials to read the report to ensure that the lessons were not lost to time.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Amazon’s Streaming Music Aims for More Casual Listeners
articles.snippet: Amazon Prime Music, available free to Prime subscribers, has a far smaller catalog than Spotify and Apple Music, but it may appeal to families and listeners who don’t require all the latest hits.
articles.abstract: Amazon Prime Music, available free to Prime subscribers, has a far smaller catalog than Spotify and Apple Music, but it may appeal to families and listeners who don’t require all the latest hits.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The music industry’s streaming wars are usually seen as having three major combatants: Spotify, Apple and Pandora.

articles.headline: Large Companies Game H-1B Visa Program, Costing the U.S. Jobs
articles.snippet: Critics say a program meant to help American firms hire foreigners with special skills is instead being dominated by outsourcing companies that move jobs offshore.
articles.abstract: Critics say a program meant to help American firms hire foreigners with special skills is instead being dominated by outsourcing companies that move jobs offshore.
articles.lead_paragraph: Théo Négri, a young software engineer from France, had come up with so many novel ideas at his job at an Internet start-up in San Francisco that the American entrepreneur who hired him wanted to keep him on.
